snippet: Last year, the Supreme Court said that corporations could write contracts that blocked class-action lawsuits. Now we are seeing that ruling’s effects.
abstract: David Segal The Haggler column observes in April 2011 the Supreme Court ruled that corporations could write contracts that blocked class-action lawsuits, and since then judges have cited the decision at least 76 times as a reason to prevent potential lawsuits from moving ahead; points out that class-action lawsuits have been denounced by businesses for decades, and some of their arguments are compelling.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the Supreme Court said that corporations could write contracts that blocked class-action lawsuits. Now we are seeing that ruling’s effects.

headline.print_headline: A Rising Tide Against Class-Action Suits
headline.seo: Class Actions Face Hurdle in 2011 Supreme Court Ruling
headline.main: A Rising Tide Against Class-Action Suits
